docs.lead_paragraph: As part of a settlement, Bayer is running ads that clarify the side benefits of its birth control drug, Yaz. Regulators say earlier ads played down the risks.

headline.seo: Bayer Running Ads to Clarify Benefits of Birth Control Pill
headline.main: A Birth Control Pill That Promised Too Much
headline.print_headline: A Pill That Promised Too Much

docs.lead_paragraph: I'd like to thank Aaron Hirsh for a fascinating series of articles in the last month. He now passes the baton to Steve Quake, the second guest columnist for The Wild Side during my sabbatical. Steve is a professor of bioengineering at Stanford University and an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute; he uses his background in physics to develop technologies to solve problems in biology and human health. He has, for example, pioneered a new way to sequence DNA, and developed a new, noninvasive test for Down syndrome that can give results much earlier in pregnancy. He is currently studying the human immune system.

headline.main: Guest Column: Letting Scientists Off the Leash

docs.abstract: To meet President Obama's call to "put science back in its rightful place," we should perhaps first reinvent the current process of scientific funding.

docs.lead_paragraph: To get the in-vitro fertilization treatments that resulted in all 14 of her children, the California mother who gave birth to octuplets last month traveled no further than Beverly Hills, she said in an interview broadcast on the "Today" show on Monday.

headline.main: Mother of Octuplets Names Fertility Clinic

docs.abstract: Nadya Suleman had no need to look abroad for the treatments that yielded 6 pregnancies and 14 children: she said she had it all done in Beverly Hills.
docs.snippet: Nadya Suleman had no need to look abroad for the treatments that yielded 6 pregnancies and 14 children: she said she had it all done in Beverly Hills.
